Gameplay and visuals and atmosphere is 9.5 BUT technical issues bring it down by at least 1.

Gameplay is good ,GFX is good so all fine.
General FPS perfomance is fine.
RTAO is not that demanding with a powerful rig and SSAO is very light and both look good.

NG+ has some additonal phantom enemies that are even stronger than the enhanced variants.(basic,enhanced,phantom)
NG+ also has an optional different ending if you collect all NG+ only collectibles.

Intesity director has some RNG so you can not always know what is going to happen.Reloading save checkpoint can change stuff even going the same route doing same things.

But usually first time entering the room will have mostly scripted ecounters.
And some backtracking stuff has scripted stuff too.

Peeling enemies flesh of and the enemy dmg model is 10/10.
Usually comboing enemies are more effiicent than just cutting eg.flaming necros until they stagger or forcegun flesh off and than plasma cutting limbs of likely only in 1 shot.

Weapons are MUCH MORE balanced than in the OG the flamethrower is a finally useful support weapon.(still can not use it in places there is no oxygen+has low range).
The plasma cutter is still the most balanced weapon.
And you can easily complete the game with just the PC and get an achievement.

Game main plot is about long as the OG likely 8-12 hours but remake has 3 side quest+backtracking for security stuff for additonal stuff likely +1-3 hours of optional content over OG.

There are no(visible) loading screens and during 90% of the game you can backtrack to almost anywhere you get a warning at the point of no return.


In contrast to 2008 OG remake is darker and Necros are tankier but also lost some atmosphere and sounds compared to the OG.Still overall it is good enough.

Isacc is also tankier than in the OG likely by around 50% more on hard vs hard......
Isacc has slightly bigger inventory size than in OG.

Isacc has more tools including special weapon upgrades,kinesis system,Zero-G system from DS2.
Boss fights are much better than in the OG.
Still eventually you will deal more dmg and likely kill necros faster than in the OG thanks to the expanded combat system.

So the combat is MORE polished than OG.

Game has plenty of accesibility options.


Neutral:They slightly changed some of the Charater Designs for better or worse and Isacc now rarely speak vs being silent in the OG.
Nicole looks like 20-25 years older than in the OG....Isaacc looks around 5 years younger.


NOW what are the primary CONS......

First of all perfomance on Steam Deck is pretty bad so do not recommend it.

Game does not fully shader caches so you will have lag issues for first time effects.
First time load does a few minute long shader caching but misses QUITE a few.(tired 3 different rigs happened on all 3).

Game does asset streaming VERY poorly so crossing the invisible loading zones will cause stutters less if you have a powerful CPU and SSD.

On my RX6800OC AMD 5 5600,Nvme SSD+rebar,anti-lag,VRR,enhanced sync enabled the hidden loading was noticable but not that bad on my weaker rig it was like 1-2 second lag/frezee crossing the loading zones.Aka travestal stuttering.

Naturally this means while general fps is high you will have spikes down.
(VERY powerful PCs likely not notice it).

Game does NOT support HDDs and many users with slower storage devices had critical mission items,event not load in aka you get soft locked.Have multiple backup saves.
Impossible diff is 1 save slot only.......

High and very high reflections are kinda poor from most angles and Imo look worse then medium.
Do not use low lights as it turns off most lights and severly affects gameplay......

FSR 2.1(on quality 1080p) is kinda weak in this game and door signs get blurred more than they should.

Turning down motion blur to zero and capping fps seems to help with travestal stutters.

Sometimes you need to restart the game so perfomance becomes unbugged can be common after changing GFX settings.....

Edit:As of this writting 22 of november 2025 the game still have Devuno DRM.

In DSR impossible is"hard" but you have only 1 life with unlimited saves in OG impossible was"very hard"with unlimited saves,lives.

So DSR does not have a"very hard" mode so it is easier than OG impossible or DS2 Zealot(very hard) difficulty.

After a few months in 2023 this game"only" sold 2 million copies(better than Sillent Hill) so EA naturally abbandoned it after just a few patches do NOT expect technical issues to be fixed by hahahahahah EA.

If you have a weaker PC or lack SSD I recommed the old DS triology but as they are old games they have technical issues so make sure to learn them before playing.(primary capping FPS for stable physic and too many CPU cores.)

I’m not usually a fan of horror games and I scare easily, but Dead Space Remake completely pulled me in. From the moment I stepped onto the spaceship, I was trapped in a dark and eerie world full of danger. Every sound made me tense up and every shadow felt alive. The lighting and sound design are amazing in this remake, turning simple moments into tense and scary experiences. The visuals make the horror feel real and the ship feels alive with fear.

Combat is smart and intense. You have to shoot the limbs of the space zombies instead of just aiming for the head. Ammo is limited, so every bullet matters. The weapon variety is excellent, and each one feels unique, pushing you to experiment and adapt. Using engineering tools as weapons is creative and fits the world perfectly.

The story is engaging and adds to the feeling of being alone and desperate. The pacing keeps you on edge from start to finish, and the atmosphere never lets you feel safe. It’s terrifying but unforgettable. Dead Space Remake is a must-play for anyone who enjoys tension, challenge, and incredible design. In the world of survival horror, it stands very close to the greatness of the Resident Evil series.

I would rate it a solid 9 out of 10.

Да, есть и недочёты. Самое заметное — изменения внешности персонажей, особенно Айзека. Другие образцы тоже слегка изменены, но это не так бросается в глаза. Тем не менее, игра не теряет своего духа. Переделанный сюжет сохранил основы оригинала, но Айзек теперь реагирует эмоциональнее и живее, что позволяет глубже прочувствовать историю.

Геймплей стал динамичнее: теперь есть смысл возвращаться в уже пройденные секции корабля, выполнять дополнительные цели, искать ресурсы и секреты. Оптимизация радует, визуал на уровне — чувствуешь весь холод космоса и опасность за каждым углом.

Unbelievable! Maybe that’s the best word for it. I could tell countless stories about this game, but I’m limited by how many characters I can type here, so I’ll try to keep it short. For me, this is the scariest and most impressive horror game I’ve ever played. For a long time Outlast held the top spot for me, but… to be honest, Outlast relies a lot on jumpscares which of course scared me, and the story is messed up too but here, the atmosphere, the graphics, and the unbelievable sound design together were a perfect hit for me, and it instantly jumped to first place. I’m a seasoned horror game player and I’m not the easily scared type I usually joke around about things  BUT I can immerse myself in games, and… I have to say, the atmosphere in the Dead Space remake is on a level I’ve never experienced before. I literally couldn’t play for more than two hours in one sitting because it was just too overwhelming. And that’s exactly what makes it brilliant. Don’t get me wrong, that’s a positive thing! After two hours I felt completely drained, and I actually felt relieved when I quit the game. Very, very few games can achieve that! The graphics are simply mind blowing, no need to say much more 10/10. The dark areas (and obviously there are many) are so dark that you genuinely fear what might be there because you can’t see anything. THIS is real darkness! The game uses lighting incredibly well. Unreal. The game’s biggest strength is the atmosphere I already mentioned. Brutal! There are no words for it. And the sounds top it all off… I never would’ve imagined I’d like it this much or find it this terrifying. As a newcomer, I’m saying this without having watched long gameplay videos of the original or having played it. I thought, “Alright, it’s on sale, let’s buy it, I know it’s a sci-fi shooter horror, big name, I’ll beat it quickly.” Yeah… sure… It turned out to be the scariest game of my entire gaming “career.” Every minute was a treasure, and I say that not as a fan, but as “fresh meat” in the Dead Space universe.
There’s only one negative I can mention but… honestly, that’s more my fault technically the start was pretty rough. I blame my not so powerful GPU, so it wouldn’t be fair to blame the game. It doesn’t take away from its value at all. I had to tinker with it to even make it start. Then some areas loaded slowly, and since there are no loading screens, I assume the game had to load a lot of assets at once, which caused doors not to open, or the prompt to open them not to appear even though they should have and I got stuck in places. But aside from that (this was only in the first ~5 hours, after that it ran smoothly), everything was flawless! Here and there an enemy got stuck in a wall or something, but it wasn’t common. I can only recommend it! If you can, BUY IT! It’s worth every penny if you want to be terrified. And the story is pretty good too!

I'm very happy that this game got remade, the visual improvement is justified and adds to the tension of the environment. Player movement and gunplay is polished, the weapons are very satisfying although the Pulse Rifle is a notable exception in how weak it sounds but there's no reason you have to use it if you don't like it. 

The one thing I wish was improved was the difficulty of the game, there are limited difficulty modes when I wish there was at least one more higher difficulty. The enemy AI has been changed from the original where they very rarely berserker charge you, more often than not they will speedwalk at you. 

Also it feels like the enemies have a more limited ability to "follow" you between rooms compared to the OG. You are much less punished for running into another room for a breather. 

Adding the ability to kinesis throw blades adds fun but I don't see anything added to make the game harder overall. The game is definitely something I want to replay but if there's no real challenging difficulty, it's hard for me to justify doing that. 

Also some weapons where changed where I think arguably the game is made easier, the Contact Beam now has "softer target" attack which makes the gun a more all-purpose weapon where I think weapons should be more specialised to increase player stategic agency and add more distinct downsides to certain powerful weapons. Because enemies are much slower to rush you, the contact beam charge attack is not really a problem. 

Mobility in your player character is improved and feels more responsive but this is at the cost of making it easier to backstep enemies to dodge attacks even when you're most vulnerable such as during a reload. 

Weapon upgrading is less risky, you no longer have to save nodes to reach impactful upgrades, it smoothes out the power curve of the player so the game is easier. You also no longer need to spend power nodes to unlock resource rooms and I doubt the game was changed to compensate this change in game economy. 

Voice acting is a bit awkward at times, but voicework was overall a net benefit to the game. People who complain about "wokeness" have an overblown obsession. 

Overall, while I really like the game, it feels like so much of the game was changed, they didn't allocate enough time to make the sure the game was hard enough to be replayed. 

7.5/10

I would so easily give it an 8 if the game were harder.

It really soured the experience for me, when I was already going into this expecting to be disappointed... I'm going to get into vague spoiler territory now, but on a more personal note I don't think this remake holds a candle to the original game. 

Giving Isaac (our main character) a voice was the worst thing I think Dead Space 2 ever did. Most people forget he didn't have any lines in the original because he played his role so perfectly as the silent engineer, going through all manners of hell himself only to come out the other side with nothing to say. Nothing but guttural screams of a man so sick of being here as he cuts his way through hundreds of former crew. The way everyone around him and onboard the Ishimura acted in contrast to Isaac, their descents into madness, hysterics and insanity added so much tension to the game, you feel like you're the only sane person left and it pays off incredibly so towards the end. In this remake it's so much more on the nose (you know what I'm talking about). The performances from some of the characters like Kyne and Mercer were so crazed and unnerving, and this remake pulls away from a lot of that. It's things like this, all compounding together to take away from an atmosphere Dead Space 2008 so perfectly created. It even gets rid of Twinkle Twinkle Little Star echoing throughout the Crew Deck, instead opting to put it in... an elevator? One of the safest places in the remake?

And regarding gameplay; the remake streamlines a lot of areas, taking away the interactivity the original had that made these really tense gameplay moments special. Because yeah it was kinda clunky having to move all those damn beds around in the Crew Deck to escape... well, you know, THAT thing, or having to move Important ObjectTM from the loading zone yourself while being chased from all sides, but those were exciting moments! The dangers felt so much scarier because dying meant losing all that hard work you put in and reverting to your last save! And the Remake throws those out!! It's such a unnecessary change. I don't like the free floating areas, I get so motion sick doing them and floating gives you such an advantage in combat that you really don't feel in danger at all. While the original was much more stiff with its zero-gravity jumping, at least it kept you oriented the right way up, with each jump requiring a set-up it meant you had to plan and even that added to the tension. The real danger in the remake comes from not being able to see the enemies in the zero-gravity areas because of how everything blends in.

At the end of the day I'm very glad I still own my PS3 and original copy, so I can always play the game the way I like, the way I remember it, from the dev team that put a lot of love and passion into their RE4 inspired sci-fi hit. This remake is fine, Motive made a very pretty game, a very faithful game in their own way, as the steam reviews suggests most of you will not care or notice, new players especially. But it bothers ME, this is MY review, so it gets the thumbs-down. I'd still like to see what they do with Dead Space 2 and 3, if they ever get the chance.

!ATTENTION!: 
This is not an updated version of the original classic. It's a 2020s Hollywood-style remake, i.e. a group of mediocre (at best) devs and writers taking a franchise popularized by people with real talent and vision and trying to capitalize on it by making their own 'modernized' version, rather than making something of their own. 
Sadly, the modernization doesn't apply to gameplay or graphics. Instead it's a shameless display of Disney/Marvel/Netflix style political preaching, along with dialogue and story writing that actually makes even the cringy writing from the original sound like Shakespeare.
Not surprisingly, from a technical perspective, the game is buggy as h*ll, and in some parts barely playable, but this has also become common for projects like this, You might have thought that improving on the original, in terms of camera control and the sluggishness of character responses to player inputs, would have been welcome, but none of that seems to have been a priority.
Yes, shame on me for not doing some research about this piece of dung beforehand and just assuming that it was a much needed revamp of the technically problematic original (which was created for the console market and ported to PC as an afterthought).
On the other hand, this was a kind of 'first' as far as I know. Someone said "Hey, see all these badly-made, politically 'modernized', versions of classic popular movies they're making, which nobody goes to see? We could do that with a classic game too!"
Don't be fooled. Just because you don't see the characteristic bright pastel colors and generic, glossy, Pixar-style, character design now associated with failures like Concord, or the obnoxiously cartoonish latest COD and Battlefield releases, this is coming from the same types of devs with the same priorities. If you got a technically well-executed and enjoyable player experience in exchange for swallowing the rest of it, that would've been nice, but no such luck.
